# Hugo series and homepage redesign (2026-01-27 08:56Z)

_**User**_

In Hugo, can we group things together by like series. So can we create a series list for all the .NET Go my migration journey, give it a name and put it on the homepage and then can we change the homepage to be more like, hey, here's a list of posts, but On top of that, like some more interesting call to action, we have this big image, and it's cool and stuff. But like, can we put something on top of it? Can we like say, hey, welcome to my content. But like, this is interesting. If you're interested in this, bam, here's your series. Bam, here's this. Bam, here's that. Here's a featured article. Bam, bam, bam. Can we do things like that?

---

_**Agent (model claude-4.5-opus-high-thinking, mode Agent)**_

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
The user is asking about creating a series/collection feature in Hugo for grouping related posts (like their .NET to Go migration journey), and also wants to enhance the homepage with more engaging content like:
1. A welcome message/intro
2. Featured series (like the .NET to Go migration)
3. Featured articles
4. Call-to-action sections

Let me explore the codebase to understand:
1. The current Hugo setup and theme being used
2. How the homepage currently works
3. What content exists (especially the .NET to Go posts)
4. What Hugo features are available for series/taxonomies

I'll start by exploring the content and theme structure.</details></think>

I'll explore the codebase to understand the current setup and what's possible with Hugo for series and homepage customization.

= \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"The Empty Interface and Type Assertions\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"\\\\\\\\ndate = \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"2025-01-02\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"\\\\\\\\ndraft = false\\\\\\\\ntags = [\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"go\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"dotnet\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"interfaces\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"any\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"csharp\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"]\\\\\\\\n+++\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nGo has a type called &#96;any&#96;. Before Go 1.18, it was written &#96;interface{}&#96;. Same thing, nicer name. And it's basically Go's version of &#96;object&#96;, the type that can hold anything.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nEvery type in Go implements &#96;any&#96; because &#96;any&#96; has no methods. Zero requirements means universal satisfaction. And that means when you use &#96;any&#96;, you're opting out of the type system.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nLet's talk about when that's okay, when it's not, and how to get your types back when you need them.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n## What Is &#96;any&#96; / &#96;interface{}&#96;?\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nAn empty interface is an interface with no methods:\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;go\\\\\\\\ninterface{}  // the old syntax\\\\\\\\nany          // alias added in Go 1.18, same thing\\\\\\\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nSince there are no required methods, every type satisfies this interface. Everything is an &#96;any&#96;.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;go\\\\\\\\nvar x any\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nx = 42              // int\\\\\\\\nx = \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"hello\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"         // \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"dotnet\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"reflection\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"csharp\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"]\\\\\\\\n+++\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nLast time I talked about what I miss from C#. Now let's flip it: what has Go given me that I'd properly struggle to give up?\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nSome of these I expected to like. Others surprised me. All of them have changed how I think about software.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n## Fast Compilation\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nThis sounds minor until you've lived it. &#96;go build&#96; takes seconds. For a large project, maybe 10-15 seconds. That's it.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nComing from .NET where build times can stretch into minutes for larger solutions, the fast feedback loop in Go changes how you work. I run the compiler constantly. I try things. I iterate quickly.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nWhen I go back to C# projects now, the build times feel painful in a way they didn't before.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n## Single Binary Deployment\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nI keep coming back to this because it's so operationally clean.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;bash\\\\\\\\nscp myapp server:/usr/local/bin/\\\\\\\\nssh server 'systemctl restart myapp'\\\\\\\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nNo runtime installation. No SDK version matching. No framework compatibility. Just a file that runs.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\",\\\\\\\"totalLinesInFile\\\\\\\":164}\\\"},\\\"capabilityType\\\":15}\",\"42516397-fc7c-4c29-b275-52eff4c4dfaa\":\"{\\\"_v\\\":3,\\\"type\\\":2,\\\"approximateLintErrors\\\":[],\\\"lints\\\":[],\\\"codebaseContextChunks\\\":[],\\\"commits\\\":[],\\\"pullRequests\\\":[],\\\"attachedCodeChunks\\\":[],\\\"assistantSuggestedDiffs\\\":[],\\\"gitDiffs\\\":[],\\\"interpreterResults\\\":[],\\\"images\\\":[],\\\"attachedFolders\\\":[],\\\"attachedFoldersNew\\\":[],\\\"bubbleId\\\":\\\"27d7ed6e-982f-46b1-be8e-6e088be4025f\\\",\\\"userResponsesToSuggestedCodeBlocks\\\":[],\\\"suggestedCodeBlocks\\\":[],\\\"diffsForCompressingFiles\\\":[],\\\"relevantFiles\\\":[],\\\"toolResults\\\":[],\\\"notepads\\\":[],\\\"capabilities\\\":[],\\\"multiFileLinterErrors\\\":[],\\\"diffHistories\\\":[],\\\"recentLocationsHistory\\\":[],\\\"recentlyViewedFiles\\\":[],\\\"isAgentic\\\":false,\\\"fileDiffTrajectories\\\":[],\\\"existedSubsequentTerminalCommand\\\":false,\\\"existedPreviousTerminalCommand\\\":false,\\\"docsReferences\\\":[],\\\"webReferences\\\":[],\\\"aiWebSearchResults\\\":[],\\\"requestId\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"attachedFoldersListDirResults\\\":[],\\\"humanChanges\\\":[],\\\"attachedHumanChanges\\\":false,\\\"summarizedComposers\\\":[],\\\"cursorRules\\\":[],\\\"contextPieces\\\":[],\\\"editTrailContexts\\\":[],\\\"allThinkingBlocks\\\":[],\\\"diffsSinceLastApply\\\":[],\\\"deletedFiles\\\":[],\\\"supportedTools\\\":[],\\\"tokenCount\\\":{\\\"inputTokens\\\":0,\\\"outputTokens\\\":0},\\\"attachedFileCodeChunksMetadataOnly\\\":[],\\\"consoleLogs\\\":[],\\\"uiElementPicked\\\":[],\\\"isRefunded\\\":false,\\\"knowledgeItems\\\":[],\\\"documentationSelections\\\":[],\\\"externalLinks\\\":[],\\\"projectLayouts\\\":[],\\\"unifiedMode\\\":2,\\\"capabilityContexts\\\":[],\\\"todos\\\":[],\\\"createdAt\\\":\\\"2026-01-27T09:20:03.091Z\\\",\\\"mcpDescriptors\\\":[],\\\"workspaceUris\\\":[],\\\"conversationState\\\":{\\\"rootPromptMessagesJson\\\":[],\\\"turnsOld\\\":[],\\ = \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"Building 3D Scenes Through Conversation: An MCP Server for Geographic Objects\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"\\\\\\\\ndate = \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"2024-12-02\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"\\\\\\\\ndraft = false\\\\\\\\ntags = [\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"mcp\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"ai\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"python\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"gis\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"]\\\\\\\\n+++\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nI've been noodling around with the Model Context Protocol lately, and I wanted to share something I've built that demonstrates what I think is a rather interesting pattern: how you can split responsibilities between an AI and a server in a way that plays to each of their strengths.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nThe project is a 3D scene builder. But before you start thinking about meshes, textures, and rendering pipelines, stop. This isn't that. It's far more minimal, and I'd argue, far more useful as a foundation.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n## What It Actually Does\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nThe server maintains a collection of named objects in real-world geographic space. That's it. No rendering, no assets, no visual output. Just a spatial registry that speaks in WGS84 coordinates, the same system your phone's GPS uses.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nEvery object has:\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n| Property | What it is |\\\\\\\\n|----------|-----------|\\\\\\\\n| &#96;name&#96; | Unique identifier (\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"Home\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"Garden Oak\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"The Shed\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\") |\\\\\\\\n| &#96;type&#96; | Freeform descriptor. Could be \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"house\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"ancient oak\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", or \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"portal to dimension X\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\" |\\\\\\\\n| &#96;lat/lon&#96; | Decimal degrees, WGS84 |\\\\\\\\n| &#96;elevation&#96; | Metres above sea level |\\\\\\\\n| &#96;orientation&#96; | Degrees clockwise from north |\\\\\\\\n| &#96;scale&#96; | Uniform scale factor |\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nWhy so minimal? Because downstream systems can interpret this data however they like. Feed it to a game engine, a GIS tool, a mapping API, whatever. The scene server doesn't care about rendering. It cares about *where things are*.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n## The Interesting Bit: Who Does I've been building software for about 25 years now, and I'm still genuinely excited about the craft. I don't believe AI will kill software engineering, but it has fundamentally changed it. If we do it right, we'll make the craft better. \\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nThese days I'm particularly interested in the intersection of AI and developer tooling—specifically how we can make LLMs genuinely useful rather than just impressive demos. The Model Context Protocol (MCP) is a big part of that, and you'll see a lot of posts here exploring what's possible when you give AI systems the right tools.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nI'm also an entrepreneur, having founded and run tech businesses over the years. I try to write about stuff I'm actually building rather than abstract theory—expect code, working examples, and candid assessments of what works and what doesn't.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n## What's in the name?\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nI started thinking about developer tooling that brought AI and devs closer together. I wanted AIs to have the experience of DAP, setting breakpoints and stepping into functions. As of writing, this is still very hard to achieve.   Table of Content Generation (newer implementation).\\\\\\\\n-   Archive of posts.\\\\\\\\n-   Social Icons (home-info and profile-mode).\\\\\\\\n-   Social-Media Share buttons on posts.\\\\\\\\n-   Menu location indicator.\\\\\\\\n-   Multilingual support. (with language selector).\\\\\\\\n-   Taxonomies.\\\\\\\\n-   Cover image for each post (with Responsive image support).\\\\\\\\n-   Light/Dark theme (automatic theme switch a/c to browser theme and theme-switch button).\\\\\\\\n-   SEO Friendly.\\\\\\\\n-   Multiple Author support.\\\\\\\\n-   Search Page with Fuse.js\\\\\\\\n-   Other Posts suggestion below a post\\\\\\\\n-   Breadcrumb Navigation.\\\\\\\\n-   Code Block Copy buttons.\\\\\\\\n-   Hugo's Chroma syntax highlighter.\\\\\\\\n-   No webpack, nodejs and other dependencies are required to edit the theme.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nRead Wiki For More Details =&gt; **[PaperMod - Now I have a good understanding of the current setup:

1. **Current State:**
   - Uses the `stepdev` theme (custom)
   - Homepage has: hero image, latest posts (10), newsletter
   - 48 posts in the .NET to Go series (all named `dotnet-to-go-*.md`)
   - No series taxonomy currently configured
   - Posts use tags only

2. **What the user wants:**
   - Create a series grouping for the .NET to Go posts
   - Homepage enhancements:
     - Welcome message/intro
     - Featured series (like .NET to Go)
     - Featured articles
     - Call-to-action sections
     - Keep the hero image but add content on top

3. **How Hugo can do this:**
   - **Series taxonomy**: Hugo supports custom taxonomies. Can add `series` as a taxonomy in `hugo.toml`
   - **Homepage customization**: Modify the `index.html` template to add sections
   - **Featured content**: Can use frontmatter params like `featured: true` or configure in hugo.toml

Let me create a plan for this. The implementation would involve:
1. Adding series taxonomy to hugo.toml
2. Adding series frontmatter to the .NET to Go posts
3. Creating a series list page template
4. Updating the homepage template with new sections

I should ask about a few things to clarify:
1. What should the series be called? "The .NET to Go Migration Journey" or something else?
2. What other featured content sections do they want beyond the series?</details></think>

_**User**_

The biggest issues:

Those topic cards are lifeless - They're just flat rectangles with text. Consider adding subtle gradients, icons, hover effects that lift/glow, or even small illustrative elements for each topic.
Everything has the same visual weight - There's no clear hierarchy pulling your eye through the page. The "Building with AI & 3D" headline should dominate more. The featured series card blends into the background.
Missing depth and dimension - Your hero image has this beautiful 3D wave, but then everything below is completely flat. Add subtle shadows, glassmorphism effects on cards, or soft glows to create layers.
No micro-interactions - A dev blog should feel alive. Hover states, subtle animations on scroll, buttons that respond satisfyingly - these small touches make a huge difference.
The blue is lonely - You have one accent color doing all the work. Consider a secondary accent (maybe a complementary teal or purple from that hero image) for variety.

Quick wins:

Add a subtle gradient overlay or border glow to the featured series card
Give topic cards icons and hover animations
Make the hero text larger/bolder with maybe a subtle text shadow
Add soft box shadows to the post preview cards

```
Hugo provides its own webserver which builds and serves the site.
While hugo server is high performance, it is a webserver with limited options.

The &#96;hugo server&#96; command will by default write and serve files from disk, but
you can render to memory by using the &#96;--renderToMemory&#96; flag. This can be
faster in some cases, but it will consume more memory.

By default hugo will also watch your files for any changes you make and
automatically rebuild the site. It will then live reload any open browser pages
and push the latest content to them. As most Hugo sites are built in a fraction
of a second, you will be able to save and see your changes nearly instantly.

Usage:
  hugo server [command] [flags]
  hugo server [command]

Aliases:
  server, serve

Available Commands:
  trust       Install the local CA in the system trust store

Flags:
      --appendPort               append port to baseURL (default true)
  -b, --baseURL string           hostname (and path) to the root, e.g. https://spf13.com/
      --bind string              interface to which the server will bind (default "127.0.0.1")
  -D, --buildDrafts              include content marked as draft
  -E, --buildExpired             include expired content
  -F, --buildFuture              include content with publishdate in the future
      --cacheDir string          filesystem path to cache directory
      --cleanDestinationDir      remove files from destination not found in static directories
  -c, --contentDir string        filesystem path to content directory
      --disableBrowserError      do not show build errors in the browser
      --disableFastRender        enables full re-renders on changes
      --disableKinds strings     disable different kind of pages (home, RSS etc.)
      --disableLiveReload        watch without enabling live browser reload on rebuild
      --enableGitInfo            add Git revision, date, author, and CODEOWNERS info to the pages
      --forceSyncStatic          copy all files when static is changed.
      --gc                       enable to run some cleanup tasks (remove unused cache files) after the build
  -h, --help                     help for server
      --ignoreCache              ignores the cache directory
  -l, --layoutDir string         filesystem path to layout directory
      --liveReloadPort int       port for live reloading (i.e. 443 in HTTPS proxy situations) (default -1)
      --minify                   minify any supported output format (HTML, XML etc.)
  -N, --navigateToChanged        navigate to changed content file on live browser reload
      --noChmod                  don't sync permission mode of files
      --noHTTPCache              prevent HTTP caching
      --noTimes                  don't sync modification time of files
  -O, --openBrowser              open the site in a browser after server startup
      --panicOnWarning           panic on first WARNING log
      --poll string              set this to a poll interval, e.g --poll 700ms, to use a poll based approach to watch for file system changes
  -p, --port int                 port on which the server will listen (default 1313)
      --pprof                    enable the pprof server (port 8080)
      --printI18nWarnings        print missing translations
      --printMemoryUsage         print memory usage to screen at intervals
      --printPathWarnings        print warnings on duplicate target paths etc.
      --printUnusedTemplates     print warnings on unused templates.
      --renderSegments strings   named segments to render (configured in the segments config)
      --renderStaticToDisk       serve static files from disk and dynamic files from memory
      --templateMetrics          display metrics about template executions
      --templateMetricsHints     calculate some improvement hints when combined with --templateMetrics
  -t, --theme strings            themes to use (located in /themes/THEMENAME/)
      --tlsAuto                  generate and use locally-trusted certificates.
      --tlsCertFile string       path to TLS certificate file
      --tlsKeyFile string        path to TLS key file
      --trace file               write trace to file (not useful in general)
  -w, --watch                    watch filesystem for changes and recreate as needed (default true)

Global Flags:
      --clock string               set the clock used by Hugo, e.g. --clock 2021-11-06T22:30:00.00+09:00
      --config string              config file (default is hugo.yaml|json|toml)
      --configDir string           config dir (default "config")
  -d, --destination string         filesystem path to write files to
  -e, --environment string         build environment
      --ignoreVendorPaths string   ignores any _vendor for module paths matching the given Glob pattern
      --logLevel string            log level (debug|info|warn|error)
      --noBuildLock                don't create .hugo_build.lock file
      --quiet                      build in quiet mode
  -M, --renderToMemory             render to memory (mostly useful when running the server)
  -s, --source string              filesystem path to read files relative from
```

_**User**_

Agreed - it's getting lost in that beautiful wave background. A few approaches:
1. Add a strong text shadow/glow
csstext-shadow: 0 0 40px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8), 0 0 80px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5);
2. Make it bigger and bolder - It should command the space. Bump up the font size significantly and use a heavier weight.
3. Add a subtle dark gradient overlay behind the text area of the hero - fading from transparent at top to slightly darker where the text sits.
4. Use pure white or near-white - The current blue tint makes it blend with the wave. High contrast white would pop.
5. Consider an animated gradient text effect - Since your blog is about AI & 3D, a subtle shimmer or color-shifting gradient on the title would reinforce that theme and draw the eye.
6. Add a frosted glass "pill" behind the title - A subtle backdrop-filter: blur() container just around the headline text.
The quickest fix is probably combining #1, #2, and #4 - bigger, bolder, whiter text with a strong shadow to lift it off the background.

**Hero Title Updates:**
- **Bigger**: 3.5rem (up from 3rem)
- **Bolder**: font-weight 900 (max boldness)
- **Pure white** base color with heavy text shadows
- **Shimmer animation**: A subtle cyan highlight sweeps across the text every 8 seconds
- **Triple-layer shadow**: `0 0 40px`, `0 0 80px`, and `0 4px 20px` for that lifted-off-the-page effect

**Subtitle:**
- Now `rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.9)` (near-white) instead of gray
- Same strong shadow treatment

**Overlay gradient:**
- Adjusted to be more transparent at top, letting more of the wave show through while keeping text readable

The shimmer is subtle but reinforces the AI/tech theme. It moves slowly (8s cycle) so it's not distracting, just catches the eye occasionally.
